jyoshu: 
 
 Look, you and I both have the right to marry anyone of the opposite gender we wish. Although for me to do so would harm me. It would be an action that would force me to lie to my family, my friends and myself. 
 It would be an assault on legitimate marriages because I would not only not love my spouse, but I would have no intention of engaging in any kind of intimate relationship with my spouse, physical or emotional. 
 It would be an injustice because it would solely be a marriage of convenience only, therefore defrauding the government out of thousands of dollars of benefits only granted to those who are married. 
 You want to talk about destroying the sanctity of marriage, which would be a direct slap in the face of any remnant of said sanctity. 
 
 So, just to keep in line with the thought pattern of the original post; I have the equal right to marry someone of the opposite gender as you do, but I don't plan on exercising that right. What I'm asking for is the right to pursue my happiness in a way that is in accordance to my sexual orientation and does not cause me direct harm. 
 Denying me that right is directly harming me and everyone else in the GLBT community.

 The government exists to protect our rights, not destroy them. Speed limits and jaywalking laws fit within this role, but regulations on "sinful" voluntary behavior do not.
 
 From a utilitarian standpoint, if we expand individual rights, we expand options, and greater options allow the individual to choose the options that make him/her happiest. From an objective standpoint, regulations on personal behavior (such as prostitution bans) close off exits from poverty. Conservatives will never stop their war against human good.
Jaxian

Huh?
 
 Let me rephrase that: If Action X can be proven to be absolutely and unequivocally harmless, even though much of the public believes that it is, I could agree with you.

 
 You could agree? I will suggest that you absolutely should agree to grant liberty and equal rights to people who perform an action that is absolutely harmless. What reasoning justifies the use of the word "could"?
 
 Anyhow, you mentioned that it can't be proven that legalizing same-sex marriage is harmless, but I don't think that is important. It can't be proven that many things are harmless, for example. It can't be proven that opposite-sex marriage is harmless, it can't be proven that alcohol use is harmless, it can't be proven that airbags or seatbelts are harmless, even. There might be some unforseen harm in same-sex marriage, but if that harm cannot be listed or spoken of, then we have no right banning same-sex marriage. Disallowing something based on the opinion that there is probably some harm, without actually listing that harm, is not an action of a free government, it is the action of a tyrannical government. This implies that the government has the right to ban things even if there is no speakable reason for banning them.
 
 What I mean is, I can argue that same-sex marriage brings no harm. In fact, I will state that right now. But such an argument is hard to make if no possible harms of same-sex marriage are listed. Without a list of possible harms of same-sex marriage, I'd have to go through an infinite list of harms and prove why each one does not apply to same-sex marriage. I'd have to assume that same-sex marriage causes every possible harm then prove that harm wrong. But a free society does not ban something until it can be absolutely proven harmless, a free society assumes that an action is acceptable unless a harm can be listed. In light of this, I would like you to list some possible harms of same-sex marriage so that this harm can be debated.
 
 Furthermore, even if same-sex marriage were not harmless (which I still claim that it is), that would not be enough reason to ban the activity. That harm would have to be weighed up against the many benefits of same-sex marriage to determine whether the harm outweighs the benefits or not. These benefits include:
 
 -Freedom of people to marry who they choose
 -Greater equality under the law
 -Better homes for children in adoption facilities
 -Eased financial burden on same-sex couples
 -Encouragement of family unit which provides emotional and financial support in times where one member is in need
 -Setting a precendent of preventing government from interfering in the personal lives of citizens
 -Expanding health care coverage partners of same-sex couples and their children
 
 If any harms of same-sex marriage could not overcome those benefits (and any others that might be brought up), then same-sex marriage should be legalized, even if it could not be said to be harmless.
MrWriteLA

(The Objectivist Newsletter, April 1963) "Proving the non-existence of that for which no evidence of any kind exists. Proof, logic, reason, thinking, knowledge pertain to and deal only with that which exists. They cannot be applied to that which does not exist. Nothing can be relevant or applicable to the non-existent. The non-existent is nothing. A positive statement, based on facts that have been erroneously interpreted, can be refuted - by means of exposing the errors in the interpretation of the facts. Such refutation is the disproving of a positive, not the proving of a negative.... Rational demonstration is necessary to support even the claim that a thing is possible. It is a breach of logic to assert that that which has not been proven to be impossible is, therefore, possible. An absence does not constitute proof of anything. Nothing can be derived from nothing." 
 
 If I say, "Anything is possible" I must admit the possibility that the statement I just made is false. (See Self Exclusion) 
 
 Doubt must always be specific, and can only exist in contrast to things 
 which cannot properly be doubted. 
 
 http://www.rkba.org/libertarian/king/Fallacies
 
 "Can you prove same-sex marriage will never cause harm/is harmless?" is a fallacious argument.

 I don't agree with this post; I think the issue should be very much based on whether or not same-sex marriage helps or harms people and society. I think absolutely no reasonable argument can be made suggesting that same-sex marriage might cause any harm, and I think that no reasonable argument can be made which suggests that same-sex marriage will not help people.
 
 With respect to the examples provided above, I admit that we do not ban everything that causes harm, nor should we ban everything that causes harm. In the case of driving, for example, although driving is harmful to the environment, it improves the lives of people by allowing them to travel great distances. Often the benefits of something outweigh the harm that it causes.
 
 But if it can be said that something causes absolutely no harm, then there is absolutely no reason to ban or deny it, especially if that thing also helps many people. I challenge anyone here to explain to me a good reason that something should be denied that does not involve harm caused by something, beside "my religion says people aren't allowed to do that" for our laws should not be based on an individual nor even the majority's religion. Why do we disallow prostitution? We believe legalizing prostitution is harmful. Why do we have speed limits? We believe no speed limits is harmful. If I could truthfully say that gettind rid of speed limits caused no harm, then I would be morally wrong to implement a speed limit.
 
 So does same-sex marriage cause harm? No; I would say that every explanation for harm caused by same-sex marriage is untrue. I have heard that same-sex marriage would increase the spread of STD's, but this is untrue for it would likely not increase promiscuous activity, it would decrease it. I have heard that same-sex couples won't be as good at raising children, and even if every bit of evidence and reasoning we have didn't suggest that same-sex couples are just as good, it would be absurd to claim that a child is better raised in an adoption home than by two loving parents, even if those parents are of the same sex. One might make the claim that someone has to pay for the marriage benefits of same-sex couples, but because opposite-sex couples are already allowed this right, we would only be preventing the harm of same-sex couples paying for the benefits of opposite-sex couples. To make everyone pay the same amount to recieve the same benefits is not harmful.
 
 Look a few posts up for my description of the benefits of same-sex marriage.
 
 One might say that same-sex marriage might trigger some chain reaction that causes some person to do something harmful, and this could be true, but it is just as likely that it triggers a chain reaction that causes someone to do something helpful. Either way, the cause is not same-sex marriage, but something else which just happened to be triggered by a chance occurance. This indiciates that this harm can only be described as isolated cases with a cause other than same-sex marriage. 
 
 Now my argument that same-sex marriage causes no harm does not indicate that if it did cause harm, we should deny it. Certainly if it did cause harm, we would need to evaluate the harm in comparison to the benefits, and it is very difficult to overcome the benefits of both freedom and equality. Even when we deny a right, we usually deny it equally or denying it does not deny freedom. When we are talking about denying both freedom and equality; we've got to be talking about something really harmful. Same-sex marriage is not at all harmful.

 A lot of people do not understand the difference between correlation and causation. A lot of people are uninformed or ignorant on the topic, and this leads them to misinterpret statistics. The truth is that gay sex is not the cause of the spread of STD, gay sex is completely safe unless used in an unsafe fashion, and the real cause is unsafe sex. Statistics never lie, but they never, ever speak for themselves. You are completely safe from STD's when you engage in safe homosexual sex. While driving, you are not completely safe from crashing, no matter the speed, and that is why many places require the additional precaution of a safety belt; none of us is willing to give up driving.

As Jaxian has posted before, it's not a matter of "absolutely no harm at all." Virtually everything can have some harmful effect somewhere. Eating eggs can give you clogged arteries, you can choke on a fishbone, driving a car can result in an accident, getting pregnant can result in a fatal miscarriage... yet we don't outlaw eggs, fish, cars, or attempting to have children. It's when the harm happens frequently enough and is of sufficient seriousness and scope to outweigh whatever benefit the action may have that the government steps in.
 
 So far, no one  has logically shown how same-sex marriage will result in any harm at all to anyone (at least none that different-sex marriage doesn't also result in) while many have shown logically how it will produce a number of benefits (and not just to gay people). Saying something "might" result in undefined ill-effects down the road is fallacious. You can argue against anything  being banned by that criterion. You have to be able to describe the specific harm and the chain of events that would logically lead to it.

As a newcomer to the debate, I have a few questions I would like to ask supporters of same-sex marriage and some observations to make.
 
 The first is that can any of you show me what difference legal marriage will make in gay relationships?
 
 As someone who is arguing for a change in existing law and custom, the burden of argument is upon you to show that there are good reasons for this change to be made.
 
 Simply asserting a right is not an argument. All rights have limits placed upon them and part of what government does is balance where one right starts and another right ends.

 It is therefore up to same-sex marriage advocates to demonstrate the need for this change by showing the liberty/right/freedom that gays could gain.
 
 So the starting point must be to show me what they will get if this is enacted into law.

As a newcomer to the debate, I have a few questions I would like to ask supporters of same-sex marriage and some observations to make.

 
 Woo, I love questions!
 
 
The first is that can any of you show me what difference legal marriage will make in gay relationships?

 
 Jyoshu mentioned 1049 benefits of marriage. This number is actually correct. The summary can be seen here: http://www.gao.gov/archive/1997/og97016.pdf
 
 If you don't feel like reading the whole thing, I won't blame you. I certainly didn't! In summary, though, the list I linked to talks about increased social security, welfare, medicare and medicaid benefits. It also talks about veteran's benefits for spouses, employment benefits, naturalization of spouses and children of spouses, military service benefits, intellectual property benefits, family violence benefits, increased ability to get a loan, and many other benefits which I'm not as familiar with. These benefits include medical coverage for children of same-sex couples, increased ability to adopt children, and tax breaks for couples with children. These benefits will greatly ease many difficulties faced by same-sex families, especially those same-sex families who wish to raise children.
 
 That link mentions only the concrete benefits granted to married couples; it does not mention the more abstract values. Legalizing same-sex marriage increases equality, certainly for both relationships will be treated equally. Legalizing same-sex marriage also increases freedom, because when the government grants benefits to one type of marriage but not another, it is promoting one lifestyle and one system of beliefs and discouraging the other. The government has no place discouraging my lifestyle or religion if they are not hurting anyone, and the government should not be allowed to do so. They in effect teach people that same-sex couples are not equal, they teach my own chlidren that my religion is wrong. This differential treatment further harms same-sex couples by teaching them a negative self-image in some cases and promoting a disapproval of them by others. Such are always additional harms of different treatment.
 
 Beyond that, having legal recognition for their marriages may encourage those homosexuals who act more promiscuously to actually look for someone they love and make the commitment of marriage, instead of continuing on in their promiscuous lifestyle. When the government teaches you that they want you to get married and start a family, that they have a place for you, you are more likely to get married than if the government teaches you that heterosexuals get marriage while homosexuals do not. This can help prevent the spread of STD's.
 
 While same-sex marriage probably cannot increase the love and commitment of current same-sex couples, fair treamtent can certainly make their lives much easier, especially when they try to raise children.
 
 
As someone who is arguing for a change in existing law and custom, the burden of argument is upon you to show that there are good reasons for this change to be made.

 
 Although I have above shown much good reason to legalize same-sex marriage, I disagree with your statement here. We are part of a free and equal society, not a tyrannical one. As such, we do not deny rights or benefits for no reason; we treat everyone equally unless we've got a very good reason to do differently. If someone wishes to persist an institution which elevates his own group over another, he had better have a very good reason to put himself above others, or he is not a supporter of freedom and equality; he is a supporter of tyranny and selfishness. The burden of proof is never on those who want equality, it is on those who wish to destroy it.
 
 
Simply asserting a right is not an argument. All rights have limits placed upon them and part of what government does is balance where one right starts and another right ends.

 
 Any limits we place on rights must have proper justification or we are morally wrong for putting that limit in place. Government takes away some rights, but it tries to protect as many as possible. We should not take away rights or deny equality without a very, very good reason to do so.
 
 
When you rule in favor of one right, you diminsh another.

 
 This isn't true at all. If I rule that the government cannot illegalize dancing, I diminish no one's rights, unless you consider the right to dance diminished because it is not specifically given to only a select group of people.
 
 
It is therefore up to same-sex marriage advocates to demonstrate the need for this change by showing the liberty/right/freedom that gays could gain.

 
 I cannot agree less with this conclusion for the reasons stated above.
 
 
So the starting point must be to show me what they will get if this is enacted into law.

 
 I believe I have done so here. Let me know what you think, and tell me what your next questions are, if you have any.

I see I am dealing with True Believers here. We'll have to back up a bit.

 
 Yes; most of the same-sex marriage supporters here are directly affected by denying same-sex marriage.
 
 
There are many advantages to NOT being married. As a married person, I can tell you that in terms of household income, marriage was a net loss.
 
 You obviously do not want to admit that in many circumstances this is the case.

 
 I ignore nothing of the sort; I do not deny that in a few cases, it is more beneficial to stay unmarried. However the implication that we should deny the option of marriage to all same-sex couples simply because sometimes it is a disadvantage is an illogical one, for it is certainly sometimes, in fact more often than not, far more advantageous to get married. Not only that, but even in the cases where marriage is financially unfavorable; it offers many benefits, which are listed in the document I linked you, that do not apply to finances. The idea that no same-sex couples should be married because some would be more financially secure does not make sense, for surely we are forcing no one to get married.
 
 This argument also ignores all of my reasoning for supporting same-sex marriage which have nothing to do with marriage benefits.
 
 
Thus if there are 1049 reasons to marry, why is divorce so common?

 
 Those 1049 benefits of marriage all benefit one's family and often require working together. For example, your medical insurance is extended to your wife during marriage. When one no longer wishes to be part of that family, many of the benefits of marriage are no longer really benefits at all. Even those which are still beneficial are offset by the fact that marriage through its nature implies family, and it is worthwhile to legally divorce to be legally unrelated. Though a lot of couples who break up stay married until they meet someone else they'd wish to marry instead. But the benefits of marriage are there; I sent you a link describing them, and I gave you an overview, and if you do not believe they exist, you are free to research them in any way you see fit. If you want to know why an individual divorces, ask that individual; everyone is not the same.
 
 
Simply asserting it, or counting bits of the tax code isn't enough.

 
 But surely providing you a detailed, many-page description is enough, is it not?
 
 
Every action has a cost, but you refuse to acknowledge this, which is why I sense that debate is pointless.

 
 I disagree. Instead of simply making that assertion, why not state what the cost of same-sex marriage is? That way I can explain why I do not believe it to be a cost.
 
 
Every right also has a limit. When you expand a right, you necessarily limit other rights.
 
 By supporting free speech, you diminish the rights of others not to be bothered by hearing you talk.

 
 I think we are using different definitions of the word "right". I use it as the founders did, as Locke did, to describe the political freedom to do something. The idea that one person has the "right" to not be bothered implies that rights can be extended to preserving individual preferences. On the same note, I might say, for example, that denying free speech denies the right of a person to not be bothered by someone's inablity to say something. If we include preferences as "rights", then by the very nature of doing so, each time someone's preference right is violated, a person of the opposite preference has his right upheld.
 
 For example, you might try to say that by allowing same-sex marriage, we are violating one man's right to be comfortable knowing gays can't marry. Through the same reasoning, I could say that you are violating the right of another man to be comfortable knowing that gays can marry. I would consider neither of these rights.
 
 
The right to self-defense is another example. My right to carry a gun is frequently countered by others who claim that it interferes with their rights not to feel threatened.

 
 I think the situation is better described as such: You want to be allowed to exercise your right to carry a gun. Other people do not want you to have that right. To justify this position, they claim that it is harmful for people to be allowed to carry guns because guns are too often misused to hurt people.
 
 
Whatever side you are on, there is a clear clash of interests.

 
 In most issues, such as gun control, abortion, etc. both sides have very valid points. Generally one side wants to take away a right because they believe that right is harmful, and they have good reasons for that. The decision then becomes: is that right worth the harm? But same-sex marriage is different; there are no good arguments opposing it, and there are many good arguments supporting. There is one clearly correct answer. You can say that I am ignorant or misinformed, but if you believe that so, why not list an argument in opposition to same-sex marriage, and I will try to explain why it is logically invalid.
 
 
You can pretend this isn't the case, but if you do, you are either ignorant or dishonest.

 
 I don't pretend, I believe. Again, instead of simply stating that I am wrong, prove me wrong by showing me a reason to deny same-sex marriage. Then we can discuss that harm and figure out whether it really is a good reason.
 
 
I came to this debate skeptical, but willing to entertain the idea if someone could make a compelling case. To me that includes addressing the same concerns every other policy initiative does.

 
 Name a concern that I have not addressed.
 
 
Simply announcing that you have a right, that your right won't hurt anyone else and that it is up to your opposition to find reasons NOT to embrace your view is no way to pursuade someone.
 
 To put it another way, the correct answer to "Why" isn't "Why not."

 
 Because we should have a free and equal society, "why not" is indeed enough; we don't deny people the right to do something, then make them prove that they deserve it. Let me ask you: why don't we ban skipping? Why don't we ban producing yellow paper? Why don't we ban marble tables; I mean who really needs those? Why don't we ban spinning? Why don't we ban insulting people? Why don't we ban saying "cookies" three times in a row? We don't ban these things not because there is some incredibly compelling reason to allow them, we don't ban them because people deserve freedom.
 
 But you are wrong to say that I have not answered the question of "Why". I posted a very long description of why in my previous post. It started with "Jyoshu mentioned 1049 benefits of marriage," and it ended with "While same-sex marriage probably cannot increase the love and commitment of current same-sex couples, fair treamtent can certainly make their lives much easier, especially when they try to raise children."
 
 Perhaps you did come here skeptical, but skepticism does not justify denying that the why ever existed when it was posted in plain sight.

Listening to gay rights people trying to get gay marriage recognized by the govt., one would think that getting married was like winning the lottery. The fact is, a lot of those 1049 or-whatever-number benefits are tiny barely consequential things that most people will never even deal with in their lifetime. I certainly haven't, and you're right in some cases it's actually more advantageous to stay single, if it's going to be about the benefits. For me, marriage is a lot more than that, and I'd be married regardless of govt. recognition. I think a lot of them actually know that most of those benefits are not that consequential; surely they aren't so naive to think marriage recognition is the answer to life's problems. I think for the most part this 'fight' on their part is more about deeper-rooted causes than that. I think they see gay marriage as the ultimate prize in terms of validifying homosexuality. There's no other explanation for why this one aspect of gay rights gets such the lion share of their activism.

 
 It gets the lion's share of our activism because legalizing this will be the quickest way to equality and because legalizing marriage will provide the most benefits for the most people of all the gay rights issues.
 
 
Well stated. There has to be a clear and rational case made.

 
 I believe that the supporters of same-sex marriage on this forum have presented a very clear and very rational case. But I still have not heard the reason that you do not support same-sex marriage. You have stated that you don't think marriage should be redefined, but you haven't stated why you think that. I have not heard your line of reasoning spelled out.
jyoshu

But I still have not heard the reason that you do not support same-sex marriage. You have stated that you don't think marriage should be redefined, but you haven't stated why you think that. I have not heard your line of reasoning spelled out.

 
 Actually, I have, but I'll state it again: Because I don't think it is necessary nor worth it to go against the time-honored and sacred values of millions of people by legitmizing gay marriage, and instead I think we should find other ways to meet the needs of gay couples. Marriage is a sacred-enough of an issue that unless there is an awfully good reason to go the route of redefining it rather than find other ways to meet their needs, we don't need to do it, and as state after state is deciding, there's just not a good enough reason. From what I see, this crusade of yours is about validity rather than marriage, and therefore you are trying to use marriage as a means to an end.
Jaxian

Actually, I have, but I'll state it again: Because I don't think it is necessary nor worth it to go against the time-honored and sacred values of millions of people by legitmizing gay marriage, and instead I think we should find other ways to meet the needs of gay couples. Marriage is a sacred-enough of an issue that unless there is an awfully good reason to go the route of redefining it rather than find other ways to meet their needs, we don't need to do it, and as state after state is deciding, there's just not a good enough reason. From what I see, this crusade of yours is about validity rather than marriage, and therefore you are trying to use marriage as a means to an end.

 
 Yes, I mean, I do remember this. But the questions in my mind then become: why do you feel that the fact that marriage is a time-honored insitution has any bearing on whether or not it should be changed? Why do you feel that something is worth keeping in law because it agrees with some people's religion, even though it doesn't agree with others? Why do you think that there needs to be an awfully good reason?
 
 I understand that you don't think there is enough reason to institute marriage. But I have argued why I think there is enough reason in the past, and I'll almost certainly do it again. I understand that you don't think my argument is reason enough to let everyone into marriage, but I don't understand why even a simple reason isn't good enough. I don't understand why something should remain restrictive simply because it is time-honored or sacred to some.
jitobear

Actually, I have, but I'll state it again: Because I don't think it is necessary nor worth it to go against the time-honored and sacred values of millions of people by legitmizing gay marriage, and instead I think we should find other ways to meet the needs of gay couples. Marriage is a sacred-enough of an issue that unless there is an awfully good reason to go the route of redefining it rather than find other ways to meet their needs, we don't need to do it, and as state after state is deciding, there's just not a good enough reason. From what I see, this crusade of yours is about validity rather than marriage, and therefore you are trying to use marriage as a means to an end.

 
 
 I don wanna let them hab it. It's too special for me and they aren't as good as me - waa waa waa sniffle neener booboo.
 
 I remember arguments like this from the spoiled kids in grade school.
 
 Selfish, spoiled little straight guy. 
 
 Let me see if I can find a used tissue in my purse for you.
BobNelson2

From what I see, this crusade of yours is about validity rather than marriage, and therefore you are trying to use marriage as a means to an end.

 
 It's about the validity of family, the validity of a relationship when it is challenged in this highly legalistic society. The "ends" involved are the ability to provide security for children, comfort in old age, support in illness. 
 
 These are not trivial issues and YOU KNOW IT.
 
 You have such insight into the inner workings of the minds of the "moral right". Why don't you tell us why they would withhold these things from fellow citizens? Is it just our punishment for being "immoral"?
Voice Of Reason

Every once in a while, conservatives slip up and say, "Both gays and straighs already have equal rights. Everybody has the right to marry someone of the opposite gender." Well, if that is true, then won't legalizing gay marriage open greater options for us all? Straighs, as well as gays, will have the right to marry people of the same gender.
 
 Of course, straights have no plan to use this right. But in our country, we have lots of rights that we don't plan to use. I have a First Amendment right to advocate fascist ideas, though I do not plan to use that right.
 
 Since this is an overall increase in personal liberty, then what is wrong with it?

 
 Yeah, I could marry my brother, sister or a pet..........I could even marry 2 women............lets go for it......... emoticon_rolleyes
wsm2506

Yeah, I could marry my brother, sister or a pet..........I could even marry 2 women............lets go for it......... emoticon_rolleyes

 
 As I said before, it does me no harm.
joebrummer

Yeah, I could marry my brother, sister or a pet..........I could even marry 2 women............lets go for it......... emoticon_rolleyes

 
 you cannot marry your sister or brother because you are related
 You cannot marry your pet because your pet cannot consent to the marriage
 You cannot marry 2 women, it is illegal. Gay marriage isn't legal, it is also not illegal.
 
 You attempt at this slippery slope fallacy is pathetic.
jyoshu

I remember arguments like this from the spoiled kids in grade school.

 
 Really??? You had discussions about gay rights as a grade school kid with other kids?? Impressive! :p
 
 
You have such insight into the inner workings of the minds of the "moral right". Why don't you tell us why they would withhold these things from fellow citizens?

 
 Many reasons for different people.
 
 Some want to withhold them because they simply don't see homosexuality as a valid reason to give such things. 
 
 Others see it as a moral delimma and feel they are standing up for what's right.
 
 And there are probably some that, frankly, just don't like gay people, unfortunately.
 
 But I'm left of a lot of the religious right on quite a few issues; I don't know that I'm the best person to ask.
Jaxian

Many reasons for different people.
 
 Some want to withhold them because they simply don't see homosexuality as a valid reason to give such things.

 
 But certainly heterosexuality is also not a valid reason to give such benefits. The benefits of marriage are granted because of a loving relationship and the need to take care of one's family and hold it together. The reasons for marriage are equal among both same-sex and opposite-sex couples. Or if they are not, what are valid reasons for marriage that do not apply to same-sex couples?
 
 
Others see it as a moral delimma and feel they are standing up for what's right.

 
 Without reason provided to see homosexuality as immoral, this can only be understood as a religious or personal belief, neither of which should be forced upon others or used to deny other people rights. Some people dislike black people or redheads or men, but that dislike simply is no excuse for denying those people equality.
 
 
And there are probably some that, frankly, just don't like gay people, unfortunately.
 
 But I'm left of a lot of the religious right on quite a few issues; I don't know that I'm the best person to ask.

 
 The problem is that we've asked the religious right about these things our entire lives, and none have come up with an answer except beyond what you've stated here. No one has stated a reason, they've simply stated "homosexuality is bad" or "I don't like homosexuality".
jyoshu

The problem is that we've asked the religious right about these things our entire lives, and none have come up with an answer except beyond what you've stated here. No one has stated a reason, they've simply stated "homosexuality is bad" or "I don't like homosexuality".

 
 Well, when someone believes in absolute truth, and that absolute truth says to believe a certain thing, it's a lot to ask that someone to stop believing in it.
Jaxian

Well, when someone believes in absolute truth, and that absolute truth says to believe a certain thing, it's a lot to ask that someone to stop believing in it.

 
 I understand that; I don't mean to say that I don't. But you've got to understand that this just isn't enough reason to deny people legal rights. We've got religious freedom here; we don't punish people of different religions. Simply because some people have a specific religious belief, they should not be allowed to force that belief upon others no matter how much they believe it. They shouldn't be allowed to force others to conform or face punishment. I'm not telling them they have to change their beliefs, but I am telling them they should change their treatment of people who believe differently.
jyoshu

I understand that; I don't mean to say that I don't. But you've got to understand that this just isn't enough reason to deny people legal rights. 

 
 I'm thoroughly unconvinced that marriage benefits are "legal rights."
Jaxian

I'm thoroughly unconvinced that marriage benefits are "legal rights."

 
 To deny them legal benefits then. Or to put a lifestyle restriction on legal benefits, if that pleases you. The terminology is not the issue; we both know what we're talking about, and putting one's religious beliefs into law, forcing them upon others, just isn't right.
jyoshu

To deny them legal benefits then. Or to put a lifestyle restriction on legal benefits, if that pleases you. The terminology is not the issue; we both know what we're talking about, and putting one's religious beliefs into law, forcing them upon others, just isn't right.

 
 Religious beliefs aside, I don't think there is adequate constitutional basis to say that marriage benefits are an example of civil rights.
joebrummer

I'm thoroughly unconvinced that marriage benefits are "legal rights."

 all rights are legal rights in this context
Dzeron

I'm thoroughly unconvinced that marriage benefits are "legal rights."

 
 Benefits? Of course not! Benefits are positive rights, that are given. IMO the only true rights are negative rights - rights that exist from birth and can only be taken away.
 
 There is a distinction between the government protecting a right and the government providing a right.
BobNelson2

Well, when someone believes in absolute truth, and that absolute truth says to believe a certain thing, it's a lot to ask that someone to stop believing in it.

 
 How can you tell when a truth is a Truth?

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Legalizing gay marriage improves EVERYBODY's rights.
